2.author: Initial
text:
A rule-change is any of the following: (1) the enactment, repeal, or amendment of a mutable
rule; (2) the enactment, repeal, or amendment of an amendment of a mutable rule; or (3) the
transmutation of an immutable rule into a mutable rule or vice versa.

15.author: Initial
text:
There must always be at least one mutable rule. The adoption of rule-changes must never become
completely impermissible.

5.author: Initial
text: All times specified in rules in UK time. Days are considered to start and end in UK time.

30.author: Initial
text:
If two or more mutable rules conflict with one another, or if two or more immutable rules conflict
with one another, then the rule with the lowest ordinal number takes precedence.
If at least one of the rules in conflict explicitly says of itself that it defers to another rule (or type of
rule) or takes precedence over another rule (or type of rule), then such provisions shall supersede
the numerical method for determining precedence.
If two or more rules claim to take precedence over one another or to defer to one another, then
the numerical method again governs.

36.author: at
text:
In Rule 202, make the following changes
— replace “7pm” by “8pm”,
— add to the end of the first paragraph “if the message is not void and all of the above are satisfied, then the submission is considered proper.”
— add a second paragraph: “The game is considered active only on days which are allocated and only between 7am-9am and after 6pm. All messages in the voting thread outside these times are considered void, including those of the form specified in Rule 214. All references
to a time length in hours and/or minutes implicitly refer to that length of active game time.”
— add a third paragraph: “This rule does not regulate messages within the points thread, discussion thread or privately between individuals.''

29.author: Initial
text:
Players may discuss any topics with any other player(s) without the knowledge of the remaining
players. The Telegram discussion thread may be used for any purposes, but messages may not be
deleted or edited in any of the voting, points or discussion threads.

0.author: Initial
text:
All players must always abide by all the rules then in effect, in the form in which they are then in
effect. The rules in the Initial Set are in effect whenever a game begins. The Initial Set consists of
Rules 101-118 (immutable) and 201-215 (mutable)

27.author: Initial
text: The winner is the first player to achieve 200 (positive) points.

21.author: Initial
text:
A rule-change is adopted if and only if the vote is unanimous among the votes cast at the completion
of the vote. If this rule is not amended by the end of the second complete circuit of turns, it
automatically changes to require only a simple majority of the votes cast at the completion of the
vote.

11.author: Initial
text:
In a conflict between a mutable and an immutable rule, the immutable rule takes precedence and
the mutable rule shall be entirely void. For the purposes of this rule a proposal to transmute an
immutable rule does not "conflict" with that immutable rule.

26.author: Initial
text:
If the number of points of any player changes at any time they, must announce their new total
followed by the change in parenthesis in the Telegram points thread. If anyone’s total is not
correct anyone else may correct it.

9.author: Initial
text:
If the number of a rule is changed, due to Rule 109 or otherwise, any reference to that rule number
is also changed.

23.author: Initial
text:
An adopted rule-change takes full effect at the moment of the completion of the vote that adopted
it. This is subject to Rule 214.

6.author: Initial
text:
A rule-change is proposed by submitting it in text form preceded by the words “Rule-change:” to
the Telegram voting thread, after which it may not be modified or withdrawn.
The proposer decides the form of the proposal is to be voted on. If they are adopted, they shall
guide play in the form in which they were voted on.

33.author: Chris B
text:
In order for any vote to pass we require only a simple majority of the votes cast at the completion of the
vote. This rule supersedes Rule 111 and Rule 204

1.author: Initial
text:
Initially rules in the 100’s are immutable and rules in the 200’s are mutable. Rules subsequently
enacted or transmuted (that is, changed from immutable to mutable or vice versa) may be im-mutable or mutable regardless of their numbers, and rules in the Initial Set may be transmuted
regardless of their numbers.

17.author: Initial
text:
Whatever is not prohibited or regulated by a rule is permitted and unregulated, with the sole
exception of changing the rules, which is permitted only when a rule or set of rules explicitly or
implicitly permits it.

16.author: Initial
text:
Rule-changes that affect rules needed to allow or apply rule-changes are as permissible as other
rule-changes. Even rule-changes that amend or repeal their own authority are permissible. No rule-change or type of move is impermissible solely on account of the self-reference or self-application
of a rule.

13.author: Initial
text:
The state of affairs that constitutes winning may not be altered from achieving n points to any other
state of affairs. The magnitude of n and the means of earning points may be changed, and rules
that establish a winner when play cannot continue may be enacted and (while they are mutable)
be amended or repealed.

25.author: Initial
text: Each player always has exactly one vote.

7.author: Initial
text:
No rule-change may take effect earlier than the moment of the completion of the vote that adopted
it, even if its wording explicitly states otherwise. No rule-change may have retroactive application.

12.author: Initial
text:
Immediately after a proposal is submitted in the proper fashion, players may cast their vote(s)
within the Telegram voting thread. A vote is cast by replying with either the message “Vote: Yes”
or “Vote: No” to support or disagree with the proposal. A vote may not be withdrawn. Any
messages sent after the player has already used their vote(s) are not counted towards the total.
Voting is completed at the end of the day the proposal was submitted. After this point players may
not vote on the proposal.

22.author: Initial
text:
If and when rule-changes can be adopted without unanimity, the players who vote against winning
proposals shall receive 10 points each.

14.author: Initial
text:
A player always has the option to forfeit the game rather than continue to play or incur a game
penalty. No penalty worse than losing, in the judgment of the player to incur it, may be imposed.

8.author: Initial
text:
Each proposed rule-change shall be given a number for reference. The numbers shall begin with
301, and each rule-change proposed in the proper way shall receive the next successive integer,
whether or not the proposal is adopted.
If a rule is repealed and reenacted, it receives the number of the proposal to reenact it. If a rule
is amended or transmuted, it receives the number of the proposal to amend or transmute it. If an
amendment is amended or repealed, the entire rule of which it is a part receives the number of the
proposal to amend or repeal the amendment.

28.author: Initial
text: At no time may there be more than 25 mutable rules.

32.author: Initial
text:
If the legality of a move cannot be determined with finality, or if by the Judge’s best reasoning, not
overruled, a move appears equally legal and illegal, then the player whose move is in question is
the winner. If the rules are changed so that further play is impossible, the player who’s allocated
day it is the winner.
This rule takes precedence over every other rule determining the winner.

18.author: Initial
text:
Each player is allocated one day a week. These days are
Chris B Monday
Dave M Tuesday
Ben P Wednesday
Alex T Thursday
Alex W Friday
Any message posted in the voting thread on a Saturday or Sunday is to be considered void. All
players begin with zero points.

20.author: Initial
text:
After completion of the vote the proposer adds the following number of points to their total
Floor((max{10, R-290})*Y/V),
where R=number of the highest numbered existing rule, Y=number of “Vote: Yes” votes, and V=total number of votes cast.

31.author: Initial
text:
If players disagree about the legality of a move or the interpretation or application of a rule, then
any player may call for a Judgement on the decision. They do so by entering a message into the
Telegram voting thread of the form “Point of Order:” followed by a description of the statement to
be judged. The player whose allocated day preceded the current day is to be the Judge and decide
the question. After considering the statement, they pronounce their verdict by typing “Judgement:”
followed by their decision into the Telegram voting chat. This must reference the original Point of
Order.
Following the pronouncement, there is a one hour period in which any of the other players may
dispute the decision. They do this by typing “Dispute:” followed by a reference to the Judgement
into the voting thread. Players other than the Judge then have one hour to each type either “I agree
with Judgement...” or “I disagree with Judgement...” followed by a reference to the Judgement.
If no one disputes the decision within an hour or a single player other than the Judge agrees then
the decision comes into effect. This process is called invoking Judgment. Otherwise, i.e. a player
disputed the Judgement and all the other players who expressed an opinion within one hour from
the dispute unanimously disagreed with the Judge’s decision, the Judge is overruled.
If a Judge’s Judgment is overruled, then the player preceding the Judge in the order of Rule 201
becomes the new Judge for the Point of Order, and so on, except that no player is to be Judge
during his or her own turn or during the turn of a team-mate.
Unless a Judge is overruled, one Judge settles all questions arising from the game until the next
turn is begun, including questions as to his or her own legitimacy and jurisdiction as Judge.
If the Judge has not invoked Judgement by the end of the day, they forfeit their position as Judge
on that Point of Order to the player preceding them in the order of days, excluding the player who’s
allocated day it is or one of their teammates. The same applies for the new Judge. Any proposed
rule-change involved in a dispute is voted on in the usual fashion, but if approved whilst still
awaiting Judgement, the rule is not taken into effect until all the related Judgements are invoked.
This has precedence over Rule 206. All other actions under dispute are delayed until all relevant
Judgements are invoked. A point of order may not be raised against a proposed rule-change for
which voting has been completed but the rule-change has not yet come into effect.
Multiple Points of Order may be brought up simultaneously. No player may have more than three
active points of order at any one time.
New Judges are not bound by the decisions of old Judges. New Judges may, however, settle only
those questions on which the players currently disagree and that affect the completion of the turn
in which Judgment was invoked. All decisions by Judges shall be in accordance with all the rules
then in effect; but when the rules are silent, inconsistent, or unclear on the point at issue, then the
Judge shall consider game-custom and the spirit of the game before applying other standards.

4.author: Initial
text: Every player is an eligible voter.

19.author: Initial
text:
Players may only propose rule-changes on their allocated day. The rule-change must be submitted
in the sense of Rule 107 before 7pm on their allocated day to be considered proper. Only the first
rule change submitted on a given day is considered proper.

3.author: Initial
text:
All rule-changes proposed in the proper way shall be voted on. They will be adopted if and only if
they receive the required number of votes.

10.author: Initial
text:
Rule-changes that transmute immutable rules into mutable rules may be adopted if and only if
the vote is unanimous among the eligible voters. Transmutation shall not be implied, but must be
stated explicitly in a proposal to take effect.

34.author: Dave M
text:
Rule 204 is amended as follows: delete everything in Rule 204 after "if and only if" and replace with:
"a simple majority of the votes cast by the time of completion of the vote are in favour of the rule-change; unless the rule-change transmutes an immutable rule into a mutable rule, in which case the vote must be unanimous among the votes cast by the time of completion of the vote. Transmutation shall not be implied, but must be
stated explicitly in a proposal to take effect."

24.author: Initial
text: When a proposed rule-change is defeated, the player who proposed it loses 10 points.

35.author: bp
text:
(Proposition 303) That the following be enacted as a new rule.
An accusation is made by writing in the voting thread "Accuse:" followed by the name of one player,
and precise descriptions of any number of trangressions of the rules during the current day by the named player.
Any player may make an accusation at any time on any day allocated to a player as per rule 201.
On each day when accusations may be made, a Penalty Setter shall be designated for each accusation made. This shall be the player who precedes the Judge for new points of order as per rule 214, except in cases where that player is accused. The Judge becomes the Penalty Setter in cases where the Penalty Setter would otherwise be the accused. The Penalty Setter for an accusation may, until the end of the day, set the penalty by writing a number of points in the voting thread preceded by "Set penalty:", with a reference to the accusation.
The penalty thus indicated must be one (but may be any) of those explicitly stated in one of the rules allegedly transgressed or 20 points if this is less. The penalty must be non-negative and can be at most 20 points. The stated penalty for transgressing a rule (or part thereof) whose transgression automatically changes the transgressor's points total is considered to be zero for the purposes of this rule.
For one hour subsequent to the penalty being set, each player other than the accused may once write either "Impose" or "Not impose" into the voting thread, with reference to the set penalty. Unless at least one player writes "Not impose", and as soon as this is determined, the penalty is imposed. If the penalty setter is the accuser, at least one other player must write "Impose" for the penalty to be imposed.
When a penalty is imposed, the accused player's points total immediately decreases by the amount indicated when the penalty was set.
Instead of setting a penalty, the Penalty Setter may write "Dismiss" in the voting thread with reference to an accusation if, in their opinion, one of the following is true: none of the alleged transgressions carries a substantive points penalty; the accusation is unclear, speculative, or spurious; the accusation pertains to a different day; or that at least one of the alleged transgressions has been the subject of a previous accusation. A brief reason for the dismissal may be appended to this message.
Upon the dismissal of an accusation the points total of the accuser immediately decreases by 5 points. There is a penalty of 10 points for dismissing an accusation except for the reasons outlined above.
A player may not make more than two accusations per day; there is a penalty of 10 points per accusation made after the second.
The general penalty for intentional non-compliance with this rule, or the misuse of the associated terminology in the voting thread is 5 points.
